caption: What a great experience of getting to know a bit more if the cheese making process especially in france too. The cheese we tried was fantastic and would recommend to anyone coming to Paris to try!

Interesting place! They give you a good understanding of how the cheese is made and all its variates. The tasting could have been more generous… they only put 3 types.. but they are totally open for a good talk and to share knowledge.

We had a great experience at the cheese museum. We have been to one in Amsterdam before so decided to try this one in Paris while here for the Olympics.  We had a fantastic guide who was so knowledgeable, friendly and welcoming. My partner is blind and sometimes it's hard to find activities that she doesn't get bored with or feel excluded from with not being able to see but our guide was explaining things brilliantly and he brought out different items for her to feel. He was even kind enough to let her feel some cheese, after a thorough cleaning of hands, that was in the process of being made so she could understand and feel what he had been talking about.  We got to then try some yummy cheese at the end of it. There is a good selection of cheese, meat, and other products for sale too in the shop which had lovely, friendly and helpful staff.  Glad we popped in now, thank you.

Nice little spot on the Île Saint Louis offering a presentation on the history of cheese making followed by a small cheese tasting. It would be nice to be able to visit the cellar where they age the cheeses and also to have more sampling at the tasting. Other than that it was a nice visit. The shop was excellent!

Fabulous experience! They have options for French and English tours which is nice. We were taught the regions of France where cheese is made and why. Also, how do other factors such as weather, the milk, process, etc affect the type of cheese. Most interestingly, we learned that a lot of cheeses are named after the family, much like wine, such as Emmental and Cantal (my favorite). At  the end we tried four types of cheeses and my favorite was the Brie with truffle - délicieux! A great cultural experience - I would go back. Also, there is a shop where you can buy cheeses and other cheese related items!

In terms of "museum", it's not really one. More of a cheese shop with a backroom where someone talks about cheese. This isn't a negative, but don't in expecting a museum. My guide was extremely knowledgeable and passionate. Need to book a time slot since that's when the guide/host will be there to teach you about the history of cheese, how its made, and the different types from across France. Very interesting. Get to try cheeses too!

We stumbled on this thinking of only buying cheese. Instead, we were treated to an informative, interactive history of French cheese-making. Gabriele (spelling?) was our guide and he was very engaging and hands-on, showing us the various processes and explaining all the different cheese types. We tasted several different varieties and Gabriele also recommended wines to accompany them. Also, upon completing the tour, you get a 10% discount in the cheese shop. It's a great way to spend some time on the Ile St. Louis!

We loved our guided tour of this charming museum. The tour is really what you make of it, as the cheesemakers welcome questions at any point. We left with a new appreciation for the cheesemaking process, and in awe of our guide’s encyclopaedic knowledge! We have already put what we learnt at the museum into practice when selecting cheeses to enjoy at home. I highly recommend a visit to this gem in the centre of Paris!

An interesting new museum that tells you a lot about cheese. One quibble: I would have expected more tasting as part of the experience. We had just done a similar tour in Amsterdam that cost the same, but gave you a better feel for the wide variety of cheeses available. And I think there’s many more types of cheese in France than in Holland.

Very disappointing place. Expensive and unprofitable. Save your money. Calling a place a museum is really ridiculous. This is a cheese shop with a back room with explanations. Tours are offered in French and English. I arrived with my family at the place, and there was a tour in French, since I speak basic French, I inquired before the tour if it would be possible to ask questions during the tour and I was told yes. The employee who promised that if I spoke basic French, I could manage. He also added that he was the one doing the tour, and that he would speak slowly. In practice, another employee did the tour, spoke quickly, I couldn't ask any questions, and my family and I stood there "like idiots". After about fifteen minutes we left and asked for our money back, an unreasonable sum of 70 euros, as mentioned for a back room in a cheese shop. The employee who made promises was no longer in place, and another employee stammered. I asked him to contact the manager / owner of the place, and after an unpleasant phone conversation with the manager, he refused to return our money and dared to say that he was not ready to lose on us. I didn't understand what there was to lose if the tour was carried out (for quite a big group of people) and didn't depend on us, and the fact that we abandoned it about fifteen minutes after it started. Bottom line - save your money, unnecessary and expensive.

We had a great time at the Cheese museum! The guide was very friendly and knowledgeable - we learnt a lot and it was all very interesting. The cheese tasting at the end was also very tasty. The museum has a wide of variety of cheese for sale so we got some to enjoy with a baguette later in the day :)

Very nicely curated museum in an interesting neighborhood on île St. Louis. Tours are in English or French depending on timing, so you might want to buy a ticket in advance unless you’re perfectly bilingual. The tour takes about an hour and the guides encourage questions. The space is small but the people are friendly, knowledgeable, and enthusiastic about educating people on the history of cheese across the millennia, the French cultural heritage of cheese, the wide range of cheeses still being produced today, and efforts to preserve this aspect of France’s gastronomy.  It is a very special place and they offer a cheese tasting as part of the tour, plus you can buy cheeses and cheese-related items in the gift shop.  What a gem!  This is a must-see for anyone interested in French culture and craftsmanship.

I have dyslexia and booked the wrong date by accident, however, the team was very accommodating and still allowed me to do the tour.  Gabriel was very knowledgable and very patient with me. He explained everything so well and the tour was really interesting and the cheese tasting selection was amazing.  I learned so much about cheese, the history and the processes. I asked so many questions and Gabriel really welcomed this and answered every one.  A great experience overall, would highly recommend!

Honest to goodness and without a word of exaggeration, the single best tour I’ve been on, paris or otherwise. Nic was so knowledgeable and friendly and took us around a part of Paris that both my partner and I have managed to totally under appreciate/entirely miss every time we’ve been. And omg the CHEESE! So, so lovely being shown some of the best examples of styles that might otherwise seem inaccessible due to a reputation for being overwhelming- the ones he chose showed the particular characteristics of each style perfectly without ever being too much for our only somewhat experienced pallets. Just such a wonderful way to spend an afternoon!

A small museum, but with a very interesting and informative guided visit. The guide was able to adapt his presentation very well to different levels of cheese knowledge in the group – to kids and cheese professionals alike. My one complaint is that it would have been nice to have more time for questions and to look around at the exhibits after the presentation. But the cheese tasting at the end helped to smooth this over... :)
Terrific! If you like cheese knowledgeable or not the cheese host is  great. He knows more than just cheese. Well worth the visit and I think of myself as a cheese snob - haha. Just great! Thanks
Excellent visit,  passionate people who love what they do and take the time to share their knowledge

As a professional chef with a French background, I know a bit about cheese but was delighted to learn a lot more about the origins of cheese making, and the cultural settings, from the very well informed guide. Plan to buy well priced and expertly selected cheeses at the store. The cheese tasting was really good, and included in the tour. If you even just like cheese, this is worth doing!

Learned quite a bit more about making cheese and various cheese types on this one hour presentation and the tastings at the end complimented our new knowledge. Our two presenters knew their cheese!!! Would have liked more time in the two rooms to read exhibits - felt rushed to leave so the next group could enter. Also, benches would be welcome for some. The cheese case has classic and unsual cheeses for sale and all the staff are friendly and helpful.

This place is a gem! We had an intimate tour with a lovely French cheese maker. They were so passionate about the cheese, I learned a lot and had a great time. Will def recommend this to my friends and family!
Excellent explanation of France and its cheeses. Tons of interesting information.
Super beautiful little French cheese museum. Very good story-telling. And fun interactive panels. And good tasting also.

Waste of time. I expected much more from this visit - this was just merely the guide explaining the different sections in the back room. At one point he also had to take out his phone to look for something he was trying to explain, I'm sorry but this comes off as unprofessional and shows lack of knowledge.
Great fromagerie. They were lovely and very helpful. Well priced in great location

In the cheese shop, for 1 hour, French cheese was introduced. Of course, France invented some types of cheese, but in terms of general classification, it is still hoped that some corresponding common names can be introduced, such as： Cheddar, Brie, Gouda, Parmesan (Parmigiano-Reggiano), Blue Cheese. Another point, they sell good cheese.
Really interesting exhibits as well as having a guide that truly loves cheese. He was very enthusiastic and knowledgeable 🧀
Had the best cheese tour from the most engaging and knowledgable guide! The cheese tasting was also amazing
Less of a museum rather a lecture spread over one big room. Missing interaction, objects etc that make museum a lively place.

Small interactive museum located on the main artery of Saint Louis Island The young people who run and run this place make commendable efforts to capture the attention of visitors. Two rooms are dedicated to the subtleties of making cheeses from our regions. A beautiful counter will allow you to create a beautiful platter for a festive end to the evening. A visit can be scheduled. Additionally, if you take the guided tour it can be enhanced with a tasting accompanied by a glass of white or red wine.

It was an interesting museum cheese You You can taste you At the end Explain how they make cheese It's a very good museum it's a small budget A very good Museum Which can be small cheeses with friends Family please reserve you

Good French that I am 😬, I went there with suspicion, I came out convinced! Don't expect a huge place but the museum is housed in an old building, the renovation is top notch and the young people who manage the place are all nicer than the last. Go there for the guided tour which lasts +/- 1 hour, you will learn much more than if you do the tour on your own. The young guide, whose first name I unfortunately forgot, was really competent and friendly 👌, the visit is very interactive and we end with a mini-tasting which could be improved (1 cheese from each family or accompanied by a small glass of wine) but not enough to take away a star.

This is definitely a great place to learn about and enjoy cheese! It's a pity that I didn't participate in the tour~ The store clerk enthusiastically introduced and invited me to try the cheese. I hope to have the opportunity to participate in the tour in the future

A small cheese museum (finally it's about time!!), unpretentious and which keeps its promises. Paul gave us the guided tour and we can feel the young man's passion for this product. The explanations are clear, he likes to get people involved and all questions were answered. Then a tasting followed. Really very interesting I recommend.
Great experience with explanations and tasting of 4 different cheeses, too bad there aren't more

Small museum but the visit is worth the detour. The museum is very well thought out. Fun, educational and interactive. Paul is a passionate guide who took pleasure in explaining everything to us and answering our various questions. And as a bonus, a delicious cheese tasting at the end 😋 I recommend

Very well designed museum, the visit is interesting, even for a cheese lover. Concerning the final tasting, given the presence of young children (<5 years) and a pregnant woman in the group, we would have liked the guide to think of them specifically bringing them pasteurized milk cheese.

This small modern museum is run by passionate young professionals. The museum is not large, which makes it suitable for young and old alike. We learn the history of cheese, how cheese is made and the different types of cheese. I really liked the interactive table on the production and, of course, the tasting!

If you want to support young enthusiasts, the guided tour is worth the detour. Certainly there will not be as much to see and read as in a traditional museum, you have to see it as an hour-long exchange with someone who knows something about it. The project is very well implemented: a renovation of a top-notch building as well as the start of a cheese factory on site which I hope will develop into the sale of products made on Saint Louis Island!
